sentences.sentence: “Bother( 讨厌 )!” thought Digory. “We didn’t want to bring him along. My hat( 哎呀（表示惊奇） ), what a picnic( 真轻松呀 ). Are you there, Polly?”
“Yes, I’m here. Don’t keep on shoving( 推挤 ).”
“I’m not,” began Digory, but before he could say anything more, their heads came out into the warm, green sunshine of the wood.
And as they stepped out of the pool Polly cried out:
“Oh look! We’ve brought the old horse with us too. And Mr. Ketterley. And the Cabby( 马车夫 ). This is a pretty kettle of fish( 混乱 )!”
As soon as the Witch( 女巫 ) saw that she was once more in the wood she turned pale and bent down till her face touched the mane( 鬃毛 ) of the horse.
You could see she felt deadly sick. Uncle Andrew was shivering( 颤抖 ).
But Strawberry, the horse, shook his head, gave a cheerful whinny( 马嘶声 ), and seemed to feel better.
He became quiet for the first time since Digory had seen him.
His ears, which had been laid flat back on his skull( 脑袋 ), came into their proper position, and the fire went out of his eyes.
“That’s right, old boy,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ), slapping( 拍 ) Strawberry’s neck. “That’s better. Take it easy.”
Strawberry did the most natural thing in the world.
Being very thirsty (and no wonder) he walked slowly across to the nearest pool and stepped into it to have a drink.
Digory was still holding the Witch( 女巫 )’s heel and Polly was holding Digory’s hand.
One of the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s hands was on Strawberry; and Uncle Andrew, still very shaky( 发抖的 ), had just grabbed( 抓住 ) on the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s other hand.
“Quick,” said Polly, with a look at Digory. “Greens!”
So the horse never got his drink. Instead, the whole party found themselves sinking into darkness.
Strawberry neighed( 嘶鸣 ); Uncle Andrew whimpered( 哀叫 ). Digory said, “That was a bit of luck.”
There was a short pause. Then Polly said, “Oughtn’t we to be nearly there now?”
“We do seem to be somewhere,” said Digory. “At least I’m standing on something solid( 坚硬的 ).”
“Why, so am I, now that I come to think of it,” said Polly. “But why’s it so dark? I say, do you think we got into the wrong Pool?”
“Perhaps this is Charn,” said Digory. “Only we’ve got back in the middle of the night.”
“This is not Charn,” came the Witch( 女巫 )’s voice. “This is an empty world. This is nothing.”
And really it was uncommonly like Nothing. There were no stars.
It was so dark that they couldn’t see one another at all and it made no difference whether you kept your eyes shut or opened.
Under their feet there was a cool, flat something which might have been earth, and was certainly not grass or wood.
The air was cold and dry and there was no wind.
“My doom( 厄运 ) has come upon me,” said the Witch( 女巫 ) in a voice of horrible( 可怕的 ) calmness.
“Oh don’t say that,” babbled( 唠叨 ) Uncle Andrew. “My dear young lady, pray don’t say such things. It can’t be as bad as that.
Ah—Cabman( 马车夫 )—my good man—you don’t happen to have a flask( 酒瓶 ) about you? A drop of spirits( 烈酒 ) is just what I need.”
“Now then, now then,” came the Cabby( 马车夫 )’s voice, a good firm, hardy( 强有力的 ) voice. “Keep cool everyone, that’s what I say. No bones broken, anyone?
Good. Well there’s something to be thankful for straight away, and more than anyone could expect after falling all that way.
Now, if we’ve fallen down some diggings—as it might be for a new station on the Underground—someone will come and get us out presently, see!
And if we’re dead—which I don’t deny( 否认 ) it might be—well, you got to remember that worse things happen at sea and a chap( 人 )’s got to die sometime.
And there isn't anything to be afraid of if a chap( 人 )’s led a decent( 体面的 ) life.
And if you ask me, I think the best thing we could do to pass the time would be to sing a hymn( 圣歌 ).”
And he did. He struck up( 开始演唱 ) at once a harvest thanksgiving( 感恩 ) hymn( 圣歌 ), all about crops being “safely gathered in.”
It was not very suitable to a place which felt as if nothing had ever grown there since the beginning of time, but it was the one he could remember best.
He had a fine voice and the children joined in; it was very cheering.
Uncle Andrew and the Witch( 女巫 ) did not join in.
Toward the end of the hymn( 圣歌 ) Digory felt someone plucking( 拉扯 ) at his elbow( 手肘 ) and from a general smell of brandy( 白兰地 ) and cigars and good clothes he decided that it must be Uncle Andrew.
Uncle Andrew was cautiously( 小心翼翼地 ) pulling him away from the others.
When they had gone a little distance, the old man put his mouth so close to Digory’s ear that it tickled( 发痒 ), and whispered:
“Now, my boy. Slip( 戴上 ) on your ring. Let’s be off.”
But the Witch( 女巫 ) had very good ears. “Fool!” came her voice and she leaped( 跳跃 ) off the horse.
“Have you forgotten that I can hear men’s thoughts? Let go the boy.
If you attempt treachery( 背叛 ) I will take such vengeance( 报复 ) upon you as never was heard of in all worlds from the beginning.”
“And,” added Digory, “if you think I’m such a mean pig as to go off and leave Polly—and the Cabby( 马车夫 )—and the horse—in a place like this, you’re well mistaken.”
“You are a very naughty( 调皮的 ) and impertinent( 不尊敬长辈的 ) little boy,” said Uncle Andrew.
“Hush( 嘘 )!” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). They all listened.
In the darkness something was happening at last.
A voice had begun to sing.
It was very far away and Digory found it hard to decide from what direction it was coming.
Sometimes it seemed to come from all directions at once.
Sometimes he almost thought it was coming out of the earth beneath them.
Its lower notes( 音调 ) were deep enough to be the voice of the earth herself.
There were no words. There was hardly even a tune( 曲调 ).
But it was, beyond comparison( 无可比拟 ), the most beautiful noise he had ever heard.
It was so beautiful he could hardly bear it.
The horse seemed to like it too;
he gave the sort of whinny( 马嘶声 ) a horse would give if, after years of being a cab( 出租马车 )-horse, it found itself back in the old field where it had played as a foal( 马驹 ),
and saw someone whom it remembered and loved coming across the field to bring it a lump( 块 ) of sugar.
“Gawd( 天哪 )!” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Isn't it lovely?”
Then two wonders happened at the same moment.
One was that the voice was suddenly joined by other voices; more voices than you could possibly count.
They were in harmony( 和谐 ) with it, but far higher up the scale( 音阶 ): cold, tingling( 叮当响的 ), silvery voices.
The second wonder was that the blackness overhead( 在头顶上方 ), all at once, was blazing( 闪耀 ) with stars.
They didn’t come out gently one by one, as they do on a summer evening.
One moment there had been nothing but darkness;
next moment a thousand, thousand points of light leaped( 冒出 ) out—single stars, constellations( 星群 ), and planets, brighter and bigger than any in our world.
There were no clouds. The new stars and the new voices began at exactly the same time.
If you had seen and heard it, as Digory did, you would have felt quite certain that it was the stars themselves which were singing,
and that it was the First Voice, the deep one, which had made them appear and made them sing.
“Glory be( 天哪 )!” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I have been a better man all my life if I’d known there were things like this.”
The Voice on the earth was now louder and more triumphant( 欢欣鼓舞的 );
but the voices in the sky, after singing loudly with it for a time, began to get fainter( 更微弱的 ).
And now something else was happening.
Far away, and down near the horizon( 地平线 ), the sky began to turn gray.
A light wind, very fresh, began to stir( 吹拂 ).
The sky, in that one place, grew slowly and steadily paler.
You could see shapes of hills standing up dark against it.
All the time the Voice went on singing.

article_info.previous: 女巫在街上引起的骚动招来了警察，大家都对女巫的行为痛恨不已。千钧一发之际，Digory抓住女巫的脚踝，利用黄戒指的魔力把女巫带离了这个世界。

article_info.share_words: Its lower notes were deep enough to be the voice of the earth herself. There were no words. There was hardly even a tune. But it was, beyond comparison, the most beautiful noise he had ever heard. It was so beautiful he could hardly bear it.

question.cn: 当女巫回到树林，她感觉怎么样？
question.en: When the Witch went back to the woods, how did she feel?

analysis: 文中提到：“As soon as the Witch saw that she was once more in the wood she turned pale and bent down till her face touched the mane of the horse. You could see she felt deadly sick.”由此可知当女巫回到了森林时，她感到十分不舒服，因此选C。

question.cn: 离开森林之后，他们到达的地方是哪里？
question.en: After leaving the woods, where did they go?

analysis: 文中提到：“This is not Charn, came with Witch’s voice. This is an empty world. This is nothing. And really it was uncommonly like Nothing.”由此可知他们戴上绿色的戒指去的地方是一片虚无之地，因此选B。

question.cn: “虚无”这地方最大的特点是什么？
question.en: What was the main feature of this place called Nothing?

analysis: 文中提到：“And really it was uncommonly like nothing. There were no stars. It was so dark that they couldn’t see one another at all... ”由此可知在这个“虚无”的地方，最大的特点就是到处都漆黑一片，因此选B。

question.cn: 谁加入了马车夫和他一起唱歌？

analysis: 文中提到：“He had a fine voice and the children joined in; it was very cheering. Uncle Andrew and the Witch did not join in.”由此可知孩子们都随着马车夫唱起了歌，而Uncle Andrew和女巫没有跟着唱起来，因此选C。

question.cn: 同一时间出现了几个奇观？
question.en: How many wonders happened at the same moment?

analysis: 文中提到：“Then two wonders happened at the same moment. One was... The second wonder was... ”由此可知同时出现了两个奇观，因此选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第30天
